[HEADING] BYLAWS of the CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER SECTION 1: Name, Powers, Objectives, Principal Office

[TEXT] Section1.1. Name - The organization shall be known as Chuuk Community Health Center (CCHC).

[TEXT] Section 1.2. Purpose - The purpose of the CCHC has been promulgated in its statement of mission and is as follows:

[TEXT] Mission Statement: The mission of Chuuk Community Health Center is to improve the health of the residents of Chuuk by providing affordable access to quality and comprehensive health care. The organization will meet the needs of clients with care, compassion, and highest quality. This mission will be accomplished with the highest moral and ethical regard for everyone with whom we come in contact.

[TEXT] Section 1.3. Objectives - The objectives of the Chuuk Community Health Center shall be:

[TEXT] · To identify health related problems and take action to promote health and prevent diseases within the State of Chuuk, to the extent that can be justified by health facilities, personnel, and funds that are, or can be made available.

[TEXT] · To participate, so far as circumstances may warrant, in any of the community, including preparation of agreement with such agencies or organizations as from time to time may be deemed necessary or useful to carry out the functions, plans and purposes of CCHC.

[TEXT] · To provide primary health care without regard to race, sex, political, or religious beliefs.

[TEXT] · To develop plans, based on documented needs in the service area, to alleviate health problems and improve the overall health status of Chuuk.

[TEXT] · To assure that proper medical professional standards are maintained in all health center activities.

[TEXT] · To adopt a policy for financial management procedures, including a system to ensure accountability for the organization's resources.

[TEXT] Section 1.4. Principal Office - The principal office of the CCHC shall be:

[TEXT] Chuuk Community Health Center Nepukos Box 375 Chuuk, FM 96942

[HEADING] SECTION 2. Governing Board

[TEXT] Section 2.1. Governing Body - The property, funds, affairs and business of the CCHC shall be managed by the Governing Board. The Governing Board shall have and is vested with the full power and authority of CCHC except as bay be expressly limited by the laws of Chuuk State or these Bylaws.

[TEXT] Section 2.2. Responsibility - The Governing Board has ultimate responsibility for the operations of CCHC. Governing Board Responsibilities are divided into the following functional areas:

[TEXT] · Strategic Planning to establish goals, objectives and program priorities

[TEXT] · Establishing and monitoring policy for partial payment of operation, quality of care audit procedures

[TEXT] · Establishing and monitoring all other policies necessary for the effective administration of services provided by CCHC, except when such services are provided under contract by a public entity whose scope of services necessitates that the public entity retain responsibility for establishing and monitoring select personnel and fiscal policies. In such case, the particular policies to be delegated to the public entity will be documented in a written affiliation agreement signed by both parties.

[TEXT] · Selecting, dismissing and evaluating the executive director

[TEXT] · Monitoring and evaluating the performance of services

[TEXT] · Representing CCHC services in the community

[TEXT] · Monitoring and evaluating Governing Board performance

[TEXT] · Approve the health center's grant application and annual budget

[TEXT] The Governing Board shall ensure that a qualify independent auditing firm or person is engaged to ensure full compliance with Generally Accepted Accounting Principles. In performing these duties, the Governing Board shall monitor compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations.

[TEXT] Section 2.3. Executive Director - The Governing Board shall approve the hiring of an Executive Director of CCHC, define duties and determine compensation. The Executive Director shall be accountable to the Governing Board for the operation and execution of policies and activities of CCHC. His or her responsibilities shall include carrying out the management functions of planning, organizing, staffing, directing and controlling the operations for the Governing Board. The Executive Director, with the assistance of the Governing Board, shall have the responsibility for securing funds for CCHC. The Governing Board is responsible for the annual evaluation of the Executive Director. The Executive Director shall be an ex officio non-voting member of the Governing Board.

[HEADING] SECTION 3: Governing Board Membership

[TEXT] Section 3.1. Size of Governing Board - The Governing Board will consist of no less than 9 and no more than 25 members

[TEXT] Section 3.2. Composition - The Governing Board shall have the following composition.

[TEXT] · At least fifty -one (51) percent of Governing Board members shall be users of CCHC.

[TEXT] . No more than half of the non-user members of the Board derive more than 10% of their income from the health care industry

[TEXT] · The remaining members of the Governing Board should be comprised of individuals with a range of expertise - such as but not limited to finance, legal affairs, business, health and government - necessary for the Governing Board to fulfill its responsibilities.

[TEXT] . No member of the Governing Board shall be an employee of CCHC (which includes the Chuuk Department of Health Services CDHS as the co-applicant) - or a spouse, child, parent, brother or sister by blood or marriage of such an employee.

[TEXT] . The Governing Board shall represent the community in which the service area is located and the individuals being served by CCHC in terms of demographic factors such as race, ethnicity and sex.

[TEXT] Section 3.3. Term - Each director shall hold office for a term of three (3) years and thereafter until his or her successor shall have been duly elected and qualified, provided, however, at the first meeting at which directors are elected, the directors may be elected to terms of more or less than three years in order to achieve, as nearly equal as possible, the expiration of the terms of one-third (1/3) of the directors each year.

[TEXT] Section 3.4. Election to Governing Board Membership - The Governing Board shall be a self-perpetuating Governing board. Governing Board members shall elect their peers and or others to Governing Board positions as needed at the monthly meetings. The Membership Committee shall present to the Annual Meeting a list of eligible and consenting proposed persons to replace members of the Governing Board.

[TEXT] Section 3.5. Eligibility - A person may be eligible for Governing Board membership if he or she is committed to the mission of CCHC and is willing to assume responsibility for his or her share of the Governing Board policy setting process.

[TEXT] Section 3.6. Vacancies - Any vacancy arising between annual meetings may be filled by the majority vote of the Governing Board, selecting an eligible, consenting person.

[TEXT] Section 3.7. Resignation - If a member misses three non-consecutive regular and/or special meetings without notice, or misses six non-consecutive regular and /or special meetings with prior notice to the chairperson or designee within a 12 month period, he or she will be considered to have resigned and will be replaced. If a member misses six non-consecutive regular and/or special meetings with or without notice to the chairperson

[TEXT] or designee within a 12 month period, he or she will be considered to have resigned and will be replaced. Any board member can resign in writing subject to acceptance by the Board.

[TEXT] Section 3.8. Code of Ethics/Conflict of Interest - A strict code of ethics shall exist among the Governing Board members. No one may become a Governing Board member solely for the purpose of furthering his or her individual business or organizational interest. In order to avoid an appearance of any conflict of interest, no member will be permitted to vote or influence the remainder of the membership vote in his or her behalf on any matter, which would serve his or her individual interest. Each Governing Board member shall sign an annual basis a conflict of interest statement which affirms that the Board member has received the CHCC conflict of interest policy, has read and understood the policy, and has agreed to comply with the policy.

[TEXT] Section 3.9. Disclosure - The real and potential interest of any member of the Governing Board in any financial transaction, contract or agreement arising in the course of affairs of CCHC shall be fully disclosed to the Governing Board at the earliest opportunity or practicable date.

[TEXT] Section 3.10. Meeting and Conference Attendance - Governing Board members attending meetings, conferences, or other forums shall dress, act, and behave in a professional manner. Governing Board members will attend scheduled meetings when on business travel or their expenses will not be reimbursed

[TEXT] Section 3.11. Rights - The right of the member to vote shall cease upon the termination of his or her membership. No members shall be entitled to share distribution of assets of CCHC upon dissolution of CCHC

[TEXT] Section 3.12. Compensation of Members - Members shall not receive compensation for attending meetings of the Governing Board.

[HEADING] SECTION 4: Meetings

[TEXT] Section 4.1. Regular Meetings - Meetings of the Governing Board shall be held at least once a month at such time and place as may be designated by the Governing Board.

[TEXT] Section 4.2. Annual Meeting - An annual meeting shall be held in the State of Chuuk at such time and place in the calendar year as the Governing Board shall designate.

[TEXT] Section 4.3. Special Meeting - The Chairperson or other majority of the Governing Board may call special meetings.

[TEXT] Section 4.4. Quorum - For all meetings, a quorum shall be constituted by a majority vote of the current members of the Governing Board, excluding vacancies.

[TEXT] Page 4 of 8



========== PAGE 51 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 453395

[TEXT] Grant Number: @ H800930720-02-09

[TEXT] Section 4.5. Voting - All questions at a meeting of the Governing Board shall be decided by a majority vote of the members entitled to vote and present at the meeting. Each member shall be entitled to one vote. No proxy is allowed. Governing Board members excused for good reason may submit votes in writing to the governing Board.

[HEADING] SECTION 5: Officers

[TEXT] Section 5.1. Officers - The officers of CCHC shall consist of the Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, and a Secretary-Treasurer, and such other officers as determined by the Governing Board.

[TEXT] Section 5.2. Nomination of Officers - A slate of officers shall be submitted as needed by the Nominating Committee to the Governing Board. Any nomination submitted must be with the consent of the nominee. Additional nominations may be made from the floor with the consent of the nominee.

[TEXT] Section 5.3. Term of Office - Officers shall be elected by members of the Governing Board at the Annual Meeting and installed as the first order of business to assume office for the remainder of the meeting. Term of office shall begin with the Annual Meeting and shall be for two years.

[TEXT] Section 5.4. Chairperson - The Chairperson shall be selected from the Governing Board and shall preside over all meetings of the Governing Board. He or she shall be kept advised of the general affairs of CCHC and ensure that all orders, resolutions and policies of the Governing Bard are carried into effect. He or she shall chair the Executive Committee and serve as ex-officio member of all other committees. He or she shall have the usual power and duties customarily vested in the office of the Chairperson of the Governing Board. If for any reason it becomes necessary to replace the Chairperson prior to expiration of his/her term of office, the Vice Chairperson shall fill the unexpired term, and the Governing Board shall elect a new Vice-Chairperson.

[TEXT] Section 5.5. Vice Chairperson - In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall perform duties of the Chairperson, and when so acting, shall have all the powers and be subject to the same restrictions as the Chairperson. The Vice-Chairperson shall also perform such other duties as may be assigned to him or her by the Governing Board. In the absence of the Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson, a quorum of the board may conduct business at a board meeting under the direction of an ad-hoc chairperson agreed upon by all members present.

[TEXT] Section 5.6. Secretary-Treasurer - The Secretary-Treasurer shall attend all meetings of the Governing Board and shall preserve in books of CCHC true minutes of the proceedings of such meetings. He or she shall give all notices required by stature, bylaws, or resolutions, and shall perform other duties as may be delegated to him or her by the Governing Board. The Secretary-Treasurer, with the aid of the staff, shall render to the Governing Board at its regular meetings, or when the Governing Board so requires, an account of the financial condition of CCHC, including an account of all transactions.

[HEADING] SECTION 6: Committees

[HEADING] Section 6.1. Composition

[TEXT] · The Governing Board Chairperson shall be an ex-officio member of all committees, and the Executive Director shall staff all committee meetings, or serve as a member as required on specific committees. All Governing Board members are expected to serve at least on one committee. Committee assignments will be made based on expertise and interest to the degree possible. Standing committees shall consist of no more than six or less than three members.

[TEXT] . Meetings - Much of the work and research necessary for establishing Governing Board policy is carried out by committees and then presented with recommendations to the full Governing Board for action. Therefore, each committee will meet as necessary to address concerns and duties appropriate to the specific committees, but no less than once annually.

[TEXT] · Quorum - A majority of the members of each committee shall constitute a quorum.

[HEADING] Section 6.2. Standing Committees

[TEXT] (a) Executive - The Executive Committee shall consist of four members including the officers and one additional member. Members of the Executive Committee are expected to be able to meet on short notice as necessary. The Executive Director of the Center shall be an ex-officio, non-voting member of the Executive Committee. The Chairperson of the Governing Board shall chair the meetings of the Executive Committee. A majority of the members of the committee shall constitute a quorum. The Executive Committee shall have all of the powers of the Governing Board when the Governing Board is not in session and shall generally perform such duties and exercise such powers as may be performed and exercised by the Governing Board. Actions of the Executive Committee shall be fully reported to the Governing Board at its next meeting, to be either ratified or nullified by the full board.

[TEXT] (b) Personnel - The Personnel Committee shall consist of three members other than ex-officio members, having the responsibility of developing and periodically reviewing personnel policies including those pertaining to grievance of the health center, unless the Governing Board delegates responsibility for personnel policy to a public entity, as documented in written affiliation agreement with such entity. In such case, the Personnel Committee will assist the Executive Director in making recommendations to the public entity for improvements in personnel policy that would benefit CCHC.

[TEXT] (c) Finance - The Finance Committee shall include the Secretary-Treasurer, who shall be chairperson, and two additional members other than ex-officio members.

[TEXT] The Finance Director and the Executive Director of CCHC shall be ex-officio, non-voting members of the committee. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum. The Finance Committee shall act as financial advisor to the Governing Board in all financial affairs of CCHC. The Committee shall be responsible for the review and recommendations to the Governing Board of the annual operating budget as well as any special grants or contracts, or any other financial matter.

[TEXT] (d) Membership/Nominating - The duties of the Membership/Nominating Committee shall be to secure nominees for Governing Board membership. In doing so the Committee shall seek guidance from leaders in -communities served when identifying appropriate candidates to the Governing Board. The Committee shall be responsible for presenting a slate of eligible consenting members for election in the Annual Meeting, as well as a slate to the governing Board of proposed members who have consented to serve as officers.

[TEXT] (e) Performance Improvement - This Committee will consist of both members of the Governing Board and members of the staff. Membership must include medical and nursing staff. One member must be the Executive Director. Patient care related complaints may be referred to this committee by the Executive Director, if the complaint is relevant to the quality of services provided, or if the committee input would aid the Executive Director in his or her mandate through grievance procedure. The Committee shall monitor the provision and documentation of care, identify problems, and monitor the progress toward the resolution of problems.

[TEXT] Section 6.3. Ad Hoc Committees - The Chairperson of the Governing Board shall have the authority to appoint Ad Hoc Committees as deemed necessary to carry out the aims and objectives of KCHC. Upon completion of the task(s) assigned, ad hoc committees shall be discharged.

[HEADING] SECTION 7: Audit

[TEXT] Section 7.1. Audit - CCHC shall have an annual audit, except when CCHC services are provided by a public entity through a written affiliation agreement. In such a case, the affiliation agreement must require that the public entity undergo an annual audit and that such audit must provide sufficient detail to permit the Governing Board to execute its fiduciary duties and to fulfill any other responsibilities required of the funding source for those services.

[TEXT] Section 7.2. Audit Committee - The Governing Board shall appoint an Audit Committee which shall review the finding of the auditor, and report back to the Governing Board on recommendations for appropriate follow-up actions necessary for CCHC.

[HEADING] SECTION 8: Executive Session of the Governing Board

[TEXT] All executive sessions of the Governing board shall be called in compliance with Chuuk State law and these bylaws.

[HEADING] SECTION 9: Parliamentary Authority

[TEXT] The Governing Board shall adopt parliamentary procedures consistent with the values and cultures of Chuuk.

[TEXT] SECTION 10: Amendment of Bylaws

[TEXT] These Bylaws may be amended at any regular meeting of the Governing Board by two- thirds vote, provided that the amendment has been submitted in writing to each member at least 20 days prior to the meeting during which the vote is to occur.

[HEADING] SECTION 9: Dissolution

[TEXT] In the event of the dissolution of CCHC, assets remaining after payment of all debts and liabilities of CCHC shall be distributed to a non-profit community service entity dedicated to improving the health status of Chuuk's people.

[TEXT] Job Title: Executive Director, Chuuk Community Health Center FTE: 100% Reports To: Chuuk Community Health Center Governing Board Salary Range: $40,000 - 51,000 annually

[TEXT] Work hours: Exempt position as senior management

[TEXT] Travel: Expected to travel locally, within FSM, and internationally as required

[HEADING] JOB SUMMARY

[TEXT] The Executive Director shall be responsible for managing the overall operations, finances and facilities of the Public Center in accordance with all relevant policies, plans, decisions and directives of and between the Board and the Chuuk Department of Health Services (CDHS). The Executive Director shall support the Board in carrying out its duties and responsibilities and provide information and recommendations to the Board as requested and appropriate during the course of its deliberations. The Executive Director is expected to carry out these duties and responsibilities with high levels of honesty, integrity, fairness, respect, kindness and competence serving as an exemplary leader who is able to realize high levels of support from others within the Public Center and in the community. The Executive Director shall not be a member of the Board except that the Board may authorize the Executive Director to represent the Public Center and vote on its behalf at various governmental, professional and community meetings.

[HEADING] MAJOR DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES

[TEXT] Responsible for the overall management of the Public Center, including: Community Relations; Financial Management; Personnel Management; Facilities Management; Planning and Marketing; Operations Management; Support to the Governing Board; Professional Relationships and Networking

[HEADING] GENERAL LEADERSHIP FACTORS

[TEXT] The Executive Director is expected to continuously strive to attain satisfactory levels of leadership qualities and performance including job knowledge, leadership, judgment, reliability, initiative, interpersonal relationships, organizing and planning, communications

[HEADING] QUALIFICATIONS

[TEXT] Minimum of a Bachelor's degree in healthcare or equivalent experience, business or related field of study; Master's degree in a related field is desirable along with a demonstrated record of obtaining ongoing job-related education and training. Any equivalent combination of experience and studies may compensate for degree requirement as established in Chuuk Personnel policies. Minimum of five years of medical/healthcare management experience or equivalent experience sufficient to satisfy the Governing Board that the job can be performed satisfactorily Demonstrated abilities in program development and operation, community relations, employee relations, grants, financial management and public speaking. Good familiarity with healthcare delivery and financing trends and issues in the industry and operat ing environment with particular emphasis on community-based primary care that includes medical, dental and behavioral health services.

[HEADING] CO-APPLICANT AGREEMENT BETWEEN CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER AND THE CHUUK DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES

[TEXT] This Agreement is entered into by the CHUUK DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES ("Chuuk DHS") and the CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER BOARD OF DIRECTORS ("Community Health Center Board") to provide for operation, administration and provision of certain primary care services in Chuuk.

[TEXT] WHEREAS, the Chuuk DHS desires to make application with the Chuuk Community Health Center Board for a Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 254c et seq. as now or hereafter amended) Grant, if applicable, for operating a Federally Qualified Health Center from the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services ("HHS" or "granting authority"); and

[TEXT] WHEREAS, pursuant to such funding by the HHS, the Chuuk DHS and the Chuuk Community Health Center Board must set forth the responsibilities of each party; and

[TEXT] WHEREAS, the Chuuk DHS wishes to give support to the Community Health Center Board, and recognizes the powers, privileges, and functions of each party as contained herein.

[TEXT] Chuuk Community Health Center Board of Directors and The Chuuk DHS do hereby approve, consent to, and adopt the following resolutions:

[TEXT] RESOLVED, that it is the purpose and intent of the Chuuk DHS to create Chuuk Community Health Center Board of Directors, a governance board, for the Federally Qualified Health Center to improve the health status of the uninsured, underserved, and indigent populations in the Chuuk community through the integration of health and human service delivery systems to provide comprehensive, coordinated, continuous, culturally competent and linguistically appropriate primary health care, acute outpatient care, and preventive services.

[TEXT] FURTHER RESOLVED, that the Chuuk Community Health Center governing board and the Chuuk DHS will work together as co-applicants to create and sustain Chuuk Community Health Center, in accordance with the terms of this Agreement and in Appendix 1.

[TEXT] Governing Board of Chuuk Community Health Center:

[TEXT] a) Shall be comprise of nine (9) to twenty-five (25) members, at least 51% shall be users of the center's services.

[TEXT] b) Shall be representative of the community served by the centers in terms of ethnicity, race, sex, age, and economic status.

[TEXT] c) Shall have appropriate expertise in strategic and financial planning, program management, fundraising, community affairs, local government, finance, legal affairs, commercial and industrial affairs, or social services agencies within the community.

[TEXT] d) No more than 50% of board members will derive more than 10% of their annual income from the health care industry (limit on health care industry representation).

[TEXT] e) To prevent any conflict of interest, no member of the governing board shall be an employee of Chuuk Community Health Center, or be an immediate family member (i.e., spouse, child, parent, brother, sister, by blood or marriage) of an employee of Chuuk Community Health Center.

[TEXT] f) To ensure against any conflict of interest, no member of the governing board shall be a spouse, child, parent, brother, sister, by blood or marriage of another board member.

[TEXT] g) Shall meet once a month and more frequently if necessary at a place, date, and time agreed by the majority of the board members.

[TEXT] h) Shall have the full authority to nominate and select all members of its governing board as prescribed in the Chuuk Community Health Center board by-laws; no other entity or entities may select a majority of Chuuk Community Health Center governing board members as well as the majority of the non-user members.

[TEXT] i) Shall elect the Board President as well as majority of members of the Executive Committee; neither the Chuuk DHS, nor any other entity may select the board president and majority of members of the Executive Committee.

[TEXT] j) Shall have the authority to remove member(s) from the board; neither the Chuuk DHS, nor any other entity may dismiss member(s) of Chuuk Community Health Center governing board.

[TEXT] k) Shall have access to information such as revenues and expenditures of Chuuk Community Health Center and other such information that the board requests and deems necessary to carry out their fiduciary responsibilities.

[TEXT] I) Shall invite the Chuuk DHS's financial management staff to make themselves available to report, clarify, and discuss financial and audit matters of Chuuk Community Health Center relative to effective policy-making by Chuuk Community Health Center governing board.

[TEXT] The Community Health Center Board will work with the Corporation to assure that the health center is operated in accordance with the terms and conditions of the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) for FQHCs and any modifications thereof, and specifically in accordance with the requirements of Section 330 of the Public Health Service Act and 42 CFR Part 51c subpart C.

[TEXT] Chuuk Community Health Center Executive Director, Management Staff, and Other Staff:

[TEXT] a) Chuuk Community Health Center Executive Director, Management Staff including the Medical Director, and Financial Administrative Staff, and other staff are employees of the Chuuk DHS and thereby subjected to the its Personnel Policies and Procedures.

[TEXT] b) Chuuk Community Health Center governing board has the authority in the selection of the Executive Director, from among qualified Chuuk DHS candidates, and to advise, direct, and annually evaluate the Executive Director.

[TEXT] c) The governing board has the authority to remove the Executive Director from Chuuk Community Health Center, but it does not have the authority to terminate the Executive Director's

The Executive Director has the authority to transfer staff out of Chuuk Community Health Centers (transfer attributed to a change in staffing pattern, personnel and/ or program requirements, or the unsatisfactory performance of the staff).

[TEXT] While the Chuuk DHS will retain the ultimate responsibility for establishing fiscal and personnel policies for Chuuk Community Health Center, the Chuuk Community Health Center governing board will have authority to establish policies for delivery services of the Community Health Center, which shall include but not limited to:

[TEXT] h) Initiation of new programs and policies;

[TEXT] i) Establishment and maintenance of collaborative relationships, linkages, contracts, or agreements with inpatient, ancillary, and other providers in the service areas;

[TEXT] j) Coordinate and integration of Chuuk Community Health Center activities with other federally funded programs as well local health service delivery programs serving the same population;

[TEXT] k) Assurances that Chuuk Community Health Center is operated in compliance with applicable Federal and local laws and regulations.

[TEXT] Any Grant funds available to operate the Community Health Center shall be disbursed by the Corporation in accordance with the federally approved budget. No disbursement shall be made other than as set forth in the budget without review and approval by the Community Health Center Board. [TEXT] Additionally, the Chuuk Community Health Center governing board will supervise the development of program goals and objectives and monitor performance of specified goals and objectives to assure the following are met:

[TEXT] a) The design of services and the selection of service sites will be based upon factors that enhance prevention and earliest possible diagnosis;

[TEXT] b) Services are targeted to the highest risk population;

[TEXT] c) Community need is anticipated and addressed;

[TEXT] d) Community members especially center users have input into service design;

[TEXT] e) Coordination occurs with other agencies serving the user population;

[TEXT] f) Services are responsive to the community health center users;

[TEXT] g) Quality services are delivered with care and understanding in the most effective and efficient manner;

[TEXT] h) Services delivered are sensitive to the community uniqueness and diversity (economic, cultural, and demographic)

[TEXT] The Community Health Center Board shall make its records available for inspection at all reasonable times upon request by the Corporation or its duly authorized agent or representative.

[TEXT] Shared authority exists in many areas including, but not limited to the following areas:

[TEXT] a) Grant Application, Maintenance, and Submissions- The Community Health Center is responsible for approval of the application for new access point and subsequent grants or FQHC recertification and submission of financial and programmatic reports to the grantor agency. The Corporation shares in the exercise of this authority and may review the submissions and must comply with federal procurement standards and grant requirements including conflict of interest standards.

[TEXT] b) Annual Budget- The Community Health Center is responsible for financial planning and budget preparation under the governing board's direction by a committee consisting of representatives of the health center board, executive director of the health center, and financial administrative staff of the health center and is responsible for final approval of the health center's annual budget. The Corporation may contribute to the financial planning and budget preparation by

[HEADING] ARTICLE OF INCORPORATION OF THE

[HEADING] CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER

[TEXT] Introduction We, the undersigned in cooperators, each been resident of the State of Chuuk and a citizen of the Federated State of Micronesia, desiring mediating value of community health centers on the sustained health of individuals and communities in general; and become incorporation organized for purposes other than pecuniary profit in accordance with the applicable laws of the Federated State of Micronesia and the State of Chuuk, and to obtain all the benefits conferred by said laws upon such corporation, do hereby mutually agreed upon, enter into and adopt the following Article of Incorporation.

[TEXT] Article 1, Name of Corporation.

[TEXT] The name of this Corporation shall be the "Chuuk Community Health Center", the acronym of which shall be "CCHC".

[TEXT] Article 2 Location of Corporation.

[TEXT] The principal office of CCHC shall be in Nepukos, Chuuk State, Fede rated State of Micronesia, and its specific address shall be P.O.Box 375, Moen Chuuk FM 96942

[TEXT] Article 3, Purpose.

[TEXT] The purposes for which CCHC is organized are:

[TEXT] a. To promote and support quality healthcare for all throughout Moen, Chuuk State

[TEXT] b. To represent Chuuk Community Health Center Services in the community

[TEXT] c. To organized exclusively for charitable and education purposes within the meaning of section 501 (c) (3) of the United States Internal Revenue law, the Federated States of Micronesia Code or Chuuk State Law.

[TEXT] Article 4, Duration.

[TEXT] The duration of CCHC shall be perpetual, unless sooner dissolved in accordance with law.

[TEXT] Article 5, Authorizations and Powers.

[TEXT] Federated States of Micronesia Office of the Registrar of Corporations

[TEXT] a. To exercise responsibility fiscal oversight of the operation of CCHC.

[TEXT] b. To select its executive director rom among appropriate CCHC candidates and shall retain the authority to advise and direct and annually evaluate the executive director.

[HEADING] Article 6, Board of Directors and officers.

[TEXT] There shall be board of Director of CCHC consisting of no more than 25 members, three of them whom shall be the Officers of CCHC. The Officers shall be a Chairperson, Vice Chairperson, and a Secretary Treasurer. The incorporators shall be initial Officers of CCHC. The qualification, terms, power, duties, and appointments for the Officers and the Directors shall, to extent not inconsistent with these articles, be provided for in the bylaws of CCHC. [TEXT] CCHC is not organized for profit and shall not have power to issue stock or declare dividends and shall be composed of members as the Board of Directors rather than as stockholders. No part of the assets, income or earnings of the corporation shall inure to benefit of, or be distributable to, its director or officers. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the corporation shall authorized and actually incurred in service to the corporation and to make payments and distributions in furtherance of the purpose of the corporation.

[HEADING] Article 8, Limitation and Liability

[TEXT] (1) No director of the corporation shall be personally liable to the corporation for any monetary loss or damage suffered by it on account of a breach of any of the director's duties to the corporation; provided, however, that such director's liability shall not be limited for:

[TEXT] a. Any breach of the director's duty of loyalty to the corporation;

[TEXT] b. Act or omissions not in good faith or which involve intentional misconduct or knowing violations of law;

[TEXT] c. Any violations of the Hawaii Nonprofit Corporation Act relating director conflicts of interest, loan to or Guarantees for directors and officers, or director liability for unlawful distribution.

[TEXT] (2) No person who serve as a director or the corporation without remunerations or expectation of remunerations shall be liable for damage, injury, or loss caused by or resulting from the director or officer's performance of failure to preforms duties of, the position to which the person was elected or appointed, unless the director or officer was grossly negligent in the performance of, or failure to perform, such duties. For purposes of this section, remuneration does not include payment of reimbursement of reasonable expense or the provision of indemnification or insurance for actions as director or officer.

[TEXT] (3) The limitation of liability provided in subsection (1) and (2) of this Article shall be cumulative and not exclusive, and shall be independent of and in addition to each other and any other limitation of liability provided by law or in any other agreement. Any repeal, amendment or modification of this Article shall not affect the limitation of liability prided in this article for any acts or omissions occurring prior to such repeal, amendment or modification. The limitation of liability provided for in this article shall continue as to any

[HEADING] MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT CONCERNING CLINICAL AND ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES FOR CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER

[TEXT] This Memorandum of Agreement made as of July 2, 2018, is by and between:

[TEXT] The Chuuk State Department of Health Services (CDHS), a government entity in Chuuk State, Federated States of Micronesia, and the administrative body for Chuuk State Hospital

[TEXT] The Chuuk Community Health Center (CCHC) Governing Board, an incorporated community board also in Chuuk State

[TEXT] This Agreement sets forth the terms and conditions under which the parties agree to collaborate. Therefore, we the undersigned, as representatives of these organizations, agree to the following terms of this agreement:

[HEADING] Chuuk State Department of Health Services will,

[HEADING] Under administration:

[TEXT] 1. Grantee of record will be change from Chuuk Department of Health Services (CDHS) to Chuuk Community Health Center (CCHC)

[TEXT] 2. Provide Malpractice coverage, directly through the government, as per Chuuk Policy

[TEXT] 3. Ensure that all fees collected for services provided by CDHS staff under this agreement accrue as revenue to be applied directly to the services of the community health center.

[TEXT] 4. Partner with CCHC and the Executive Director and staff to develop health information policies and system that ensure continuity of patient care and the efficient and accurate flow of patient information among CCHC sites, CDHS public health and CDHS Chuuk State Hospital.

[TEXT] 5. Make members of the CDHS senior management team available for 330 Community health Center governance and management training, when provided by the pacific Island Primary Care Association for the CCHC board and senior management.

[TEXT] 6. Collaborate on training opportunity for health-related professions, when they arise.

[HEADING] Under DHS Clinical:

[TEXT] 7. Grant admitting privileges to the health center's physicians if they meet the criteria and follow protocols established by hospital.

[TEXT] 8. Promote and support the delivery of quality continuous care and services.

[TEXT] 9. Provide medically necessary Emergency Department services to CCHC patients regardless of ability to pay.

[TEXT] 10. Refer patients visiting the Emergency Department of health center if they arrived for non- emergency types of visits or for conditions that could have been prevented if seen earlier in the primary care setting. For visits the hospital deems more appropriate for primary care providers and not requiring services of an emergency department, the hospital will refer those patients to the health center.

[TEXT] Funding Opportunity Number: HRSA-26-004 Received Date: 12/3/2025 4:49:01 PM



========== PAGE 78 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243095 Grant Number: 6 H80CS30720-09-03

[TEXT] 11. Provide all specialty services to CCHC patients, within the constraints of Chuuk resources, not available through the health center. Such specialty services will include specialists for medical (including Labor and Delivery, and regular OB/GYN clinic out site at the CHC location), dental and behavior health.

[TEXT] 12. Provide inpatient services to CCHC patients, including off-island referrals in keeping with Chuuk DHS referral policies and within the constraints of Chuuk State resources. The Hospital and CCHC will agree to a protocol for ensuring that admissions and discharges are undertaken in a manner that most benefits the patients and his or her family, including effective information sharing between providers and staff from hospital and CCHC.

[TEXT] 13. Provide necessary laboratory and radiology services to CCHC patients, in keeping with Chuuk DHS policies that prohibit denying patients service based upon ability to pay. Chuuk DHS and CCHC will agree to a protocol that ensures referrals are made and accepted, and information, including test results, is exchanged in a timely manner.

[TEXT] 14. Make CDHS dental operatories at Chuuk State Hospital available to CHC dental staff for regularly scheduled clinics for the Nepukos CHC target population.

[HEADING] Under Public Health:

[TEXT] 15. Provide public health clinics targeting the CHC service population, one half day each, for well-baby, non-communicable diseases, prenatal and antenatal services, at each of the three CCHC sites, in close coordination with CHC staff.

[TEXT] 16. Partner with CHC Executive Director and staff to develop and implement an effective case management system linking public health diseases registries and CHC clinical and paraprofessional staff, for coordinated PH-CHC service provision, patient tracking, case management and reporting for PH and CHC clients.

[TEXT] 17. Provide programmatic supervision and training support for CHC behavioral health student counselors working out of Sapuk, Nepukos and Neauo CHC sites.

[TEXT] 18. Make CDHS public health specialists in behavioral health, non-communicable diseases, environmental health, family planning, and other service areas relevant to the CHC target population available to train CHC in screening, intervention, and referral to the area of PH specialty and appropriate to job and target population of the CHC staff person(s).

[HEADING] Chuuk Community Health Center Governing Board will:

[TEXT] 19. Provide primary care service to patients referred by hospital to CCHC and share information

[TEXT] 20. Assist with planning and implementing periodic community needs assessments to ensure services of CCHC are responsive and appropriate to the community.

[TEXT] 21. Agree to a protocol for ensuring that specialty and inpatient services, including admissions and discharges are undertaken in a manner that most benefits the patient and his or her family, including effective information sharing between providers and staff from CCHC and the hospital.

[TEXT] 22. Deem the 330 Community Health center SAC application, submitted by CCHC this September 2018, along with all budgets and services described therein.

[HEADING] CHUUK COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTER

[HEADING] Sliding Fee Discount Program and Related Billing and Collections Policies and Procedures

[TEXT] CCHC's Board of Directors (co-applicant board) Approved:

[TEXT] Purpose:

[TEXT] To establish a sliding fee discount program that will comply with the Chuuk State Constitution and the Chuuk's government health services (Article X education and Health Section 6) and HRSA's Sliding Fee requirement as outlined in the in Policy Inform Health Center Program Compliance Manual chapter 9.

[TEXT] Policy:

[TEXT] CHC provides a Sliding Fee Discount Program for all patients based on income and family size only. No patient is denied care based on inability to pay in accordance with Chuuk's State constitution and no patient is discriminated against in the distribution of medical care.

[TEXT] A nominal flat amount will be charged for patients with at or below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL). The nominal fee will be evaluated at a minimum once every third year or sooner if determined necessary ensure it is not a barrier to care from the patients prospective. There will be three discount classes for patients above 100% up to 200% of the FPL. Individuals and families with annual income above two hundred percent (200%) of the FPL are not eligible for sliding fee discount program.

[TEXT] A schedule of fees will be maintained that is consistent with the CCHC's locally prevailing rates and designed to cover CCHC's reasonable costs of operations (Charge Master). The schedule of fees/charge master will be approved by the Board of Directors and updated as needed but at a minimum once every three years.

[TEXT] Collections of payments for services will be made through reasonable effort and CCHC will establish systems for billing and collections with respect to third party payors once such systems are available in Chuuk.

[TEXT] The Federal Poverty Levels will be updated annually within a reasonable time of the published annual Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG). CHC's Sliding Fee Discount Program P & P will be approved by the board of directors and staff will be trained on the approved policy.

[HEADING] Procedure:

[HEADING] 1. Sliding Fee Discount Notification

[TEXT] 1.1 CHC will ensure all patients are informed of their Sliding Fee Discount Program through the combination of one or more of the following methods:



========== PAGE 83 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS30720-09-03

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243095

[TEXT] a) staff notify the patients at time of registration b) signs in the lobby/waiting areas (see Exhibit "A "below) at each site.

[TEXT] 1.2 All communication with patients will be in the patient's literacy level and language (English and Chuukese).

[TEXT] 1.3 All communication with patients will be done in a culturally sensitive manner and will be delivered in a respectful and confidential way. All patients will be treated equally and the sliding fee discount program will be uniformly applied to all patients.

[HEADING] 2. Family and Income (Eligibility)

[TEXT] 2.1 98% of the population of Chuuk live below 200% of the US Federal Poverty Level and a significant percent of the population lives a subsistence life style and a as high 38% unemployment, qualifying them for a nominal fee under CCHC's sliding fee discount program. A self-declaration of income and family size is being used under CCHC"s sliding fee policy for patients who do not receive a pay stub.

[TEXT] 2.2 Family size will therefore be defined as husband, wife, children by blood or adoption and is based on self-declaration.

[TEXT] 2.3 Income is defined as Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) if a patient files a tax return and if no tax return is filed income is defined as any source of income for which the family receives based on a self-declaration.

[TEXT] 2.4 No further documentation is required for income or family size verification for self- declaration.

[HEADING] 3. Eligibility Period

[TEXT] 3.1 CCHC's eligibility period will be for a 12 month period or if there is any major change to the family size or income. The patient will be required to inform CCHC's staff of any changes if they occur before the 12 month period.

[HEADING] 4. Nominal Fee

[TEXT] 4.1 The nominal fee will be set at $1.00 for patient whose income is 100% or below the Federal Poverty Level. This amount is considered nominal from the patient prospective and does not cover the true cost of the care.

[HEADING] 5. Sliding Scale

[TEXT] 5.1 CCHC has three sliding fee discount pay classes/categories for individuals and families with income above 100% of the FPL and at or below 200% of the FPL. Income threshold for sliding fee is categories into the following discount classes.

[TEXT] Categories/Discount Classes:

[TEXT] A = 100% or below FPL

[TEXT] B = >100% -133% FPL

[TEXT] C = >133%-166% FPL

[TEXT] D = >166%-200% FPL

[TEXT] E = >200% or greater of FPL - No Discount- 100% of Fee Schedule/Charge Master as established by CCHC.



========== PAGE 84 (from PDF footer) ==========

[TEXT] EHB Application Number: 243095

[TEXT] Grant Number: 6 H80CS30720-09-03

[TEXT] 5.2 Under CCHC's current SFDP, the nominal amount for the patient in category A would not pay more than the fee paid by a patient in the first SFDS class above the 100% of the FPG.

[HEADING] 6. Waiver of fees

[TEXT] 6.1 CCHC will ensure that no patient is denied care base on ability to pay and accordingly the waiver of fees will occur on a case by case basis.

[TEXT] 6.2 The CEO will be the only one allowed to waive fees based on hardship situation which would cause a barrier to care for a patient. Justification for such waiver will be document and signed off by the CEO and an waiver adjustment code will be set up so that these accounts can be tracked and if necessary used to evaluate the nominal fee amount in the future.

[HEADING] 7. Covered Services

[TEXT] 7.1 All services provided by CCHC and included in the Center's scope of project are covered as part of the Sliding Fee Discount Program (in accordance with Form 5a).

[HEADING] 8. Charge Master/Fee Schedule and Billing Reimbursement

[TEXT] 8.1 Chuuk residents are not asked to contribute payments to their care at the Chuuk Department of Health Services, including the hospital and there are no other health care providers in Chuuk besides the hospital or the CCHC. Accordingly, the prevailing rates for CCHC are zero and patients are unaccustomed to contribute funds to one's own health care. CCHC has had to develop a fee schedule/charge master that is closer to the prevailing rates of zero than their cost to be culturally sensitive and evaluate the impact of this policy.

[TEXT] 8.2 The Fee Schedule/Charge Master is currently as follows:

[TEXT] Service

[TEXT] Charge Master

[TEXT] Office Visits (Medical/Dental/BH)

[TEXT] $5.00

[TEXT] 8.2 CCHC will only charge for one medical encounter (face to face with licensed medical provider), one dental encounter (face to face with licensed dental provider) and mental health encounter (face to face with certified or licensed mental health care professional) at the establish scheduled fee.

[TEXT] 8.3 For reimbursement and billing purposes, multiple medical encounters within the CCHC, which take place on the same day at a single location, constitute a single visit.

[TEXT] 8.4 Mental health care services that are integrated in the delivery of medical care shall be deemed a medical encounter and constitute a single visit.

[TEXT] 8.5 Multiple dental encounters with more than one dental practitioner in the CCHC or with the same dental practitioner, which take place on the same day at a single location, constitutes a single visit.

[TEXT] 8.6 CCHC may bill for one medical encounter, one dental encounter and one mental health encounter per patient per day

[TEXT] 8.7 The fee schedule/charge master as outlined above is adopted by the CCHC's Board of Directors as part of the approval of this policy. The fee schedule/charge master will be evaluated and updated as needed but at a minimum once every three years.

[HEADING] 9. Referrals

[TEXT] 9.1 Referral services and sliding fee is not an issue for CCHC since as a co-applicant with the government of Chuuk, all services are provided by a single health care system under the Chuuk State government (Chuuk State Department of Health Services(CDHS) which also operate the Chuuk State Hospital). CCHC has an memorandum of agreement with CDHS for all referral services including inpatient, ER, diagnosis services and public health services not performed by CCHC which requires CDHS to see all patients regardless of ability to pay. The agreement also requires the coordination of care between the two parties.

[HEADING] 10. Refusal to pay

[TEXT] 10.1 CCHC has decided to not have a 'Refusal to pay" policy, since this is not a HRSA requirement and would is not culturally acceptable.

[HEADING] 11. Evaluation of SFDP & Nominal fee & Federal Poverty Guideline update

[TEXT] 11.1 The nominal (fee/recipient copayment) is a fixed amount and does not reflect the true cost of the services provided and has been determined by CCHC to be considered nominal from the patient's perspective. CCHC's Board of Directors agree and will evaluate the nominal amount from the patient prospective by one or more of the following methods at a minimum once every three years or sooner if a need is determined:

[TEXT] a) Patient Feedback/survives

[TEXT] b) Staff feed/collection rates/# of waiver of charges approved by CEO

[TEXT] c) Establishing a subcommittee of consumer board to discuss/assess.

[TEXT] d) Other factors such as economic conditions impacting the population of Chuuk at large, legislative changes, etc.

[HEADING] 12. Collections

[TEXT] 12.1 Payment of the nominal (fee/recipient copayment) will be collected at the time of the service.

[TEXT] 12.2 CCHC will maintain uniform payment terms for all patients and all patients will be treated with respect and in a confidential manner and no patient will be denied service based on inability to pay.

[TEXT] 12.3 Payment terms, if needed, will be set up with the patient using the Payment Plan Agreement Form. The form will be sign by the patient and by a CCHC Administration staff for outstanding balances less than $10.00. For amounts greater than the $10,00 payment terms will be approved by the Operations Manager on a case by case basis and be consistent. No patient is refused care due inability to pay.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Update of Needs Assessment
compliantItems.requirement: The health center completes or updates a needs assessment of the current or proposed population at least once every three years, for the purposes of informing and improving the delivery of health center services. The needs assessment utilizes the most recently available data for the service area and, if applicable, special populations and addresses the following:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center completes or updates a needs assessment at least once every three years, using current data, and addresses all three required items.
compliantItems.evidence: "How the service area is annually reviewed - The service area is the entire island and population of Weno; hence there is no opportunity to expand or adjust the service area of the existing health center without a New Access Point application to HRSA for the lagoon and/or outer islands, such as Faichuk or the Mortlocks. The CHCC Board of Directors anticipates submitting an NAP for Faichuk in the near future." "Geographical/transportation barriers - Transportation is a significant barrier to primary health care access. Sixty percent (60%) of households have no transportation..." "Chuuk is the most populated and has the poorest health profile of the four FSM states. There are numerous indications that poor access to care impairs the health of the population in Chuuk. The life expectancy of under 66 years in Chuuk state is far lower than the US (78 years)... Like most of Micronesia, Chuuk has experienced an epidemiological transition wherein diabetes, cardiovascular diseases and cancers have emerged even as infectious and nutritional deficiency diseases continue to exact a heavy toll." "Fifty percent of households in Chuuk Lagoon have no sewer or sanitary waste disposal... Chuuk is susceptible to periodic outbreaks of dengue fever, leptospirosis, gastroenteritis, amoeba, and has a constant burden of intestinal helminthes that contribute to childhood malnutrition, anemia, and premature births... Chuuk is for the most part culturally and linguistically homogeneous. According to the 2010 FSM Census, 99% of Chuuk residents are Chuukese. English is spoken as a second language by most residents. All CHC staff will be bilingual in English and Chuukese..."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates a triennial needs assessment using current data, addressing access/utilization factors, morbidity/mortality, and unique health needs. (1) Frequency and update of assessment is SATISFIED: the application describes annual review and references ongoing needs assessment. (2) Access/utilization factors are SATISFIED: explicit discussion of transportation, income, education, and insurance barriers. (3) Significant causes of morbidity/mortality are SATISFIED: detailed data on NCDs, infant mortality, and health disparities. (4) Unique health needs/characteristics are SATISFIED: discussion of social, environmental, and cultural factors. All required items are explicitly addressed with direct evidence; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Sliding Fee Discount Program Policies
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has board-approved policy(ies) for its sliding fee discount program that apply uniformly to all patients and address the following areas:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of board-approved sliding fee discount program policies addressing definitions, eligibility, structure, and nominal charge requirements.
compliantItems.evidence: "Family size will therefore be defined as husband, wife, children by blood or adoption and is based on self-declaration. Income is defined as Adjusted Gross Income (AGI) if a patient files a tax return and if no tax return is filed income is defined as any source of income for which the family receives based on a self-declaration." "The Sliding Fee Discount Program is provided for all patients based on income and family size only. No patient is denied care based on inability to pay..." "A nominal flat amount will be charged for patients with at or below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL)... The nominal fee will be evaluated at a minimum once every third year or sooner if determined necessary ensure it is not a barrier to care from the patients prospective." "A schedule of fees will be maintained... approved by the Board of Directors and updated as needed but at a minimum once every three years."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates board-approved sliding fee discount program policies that address definitions of income/family, eligibility assessment based only on income/family size, structure of the SFDS, and nominal charge setting. All four items were checked: (1) definitions of income/family—SATISFIED: explicit definitions provided; (2) assessment based only on income/family size—SATISFIED: policy states eligibility is based only on these factors; (3) SFDS structure—SATISFIED: discount classes and board approval process described; (4) nominal charge—SATISFIED: nominal fee set, rationale and evaluation process described. All items are explicitly addressed in board-approved policy, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element c - Sliding Fee for Column I Services
compliantItems.requirement: For services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Services Provided, Column I), the health center's SFDS(s) is structured consistent with its policy and provides discounts as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of the Sliding Fee Discount Program (SFDS) structure for services provided directly by the health center (Form 5A: Column I), specifically for compliance with HRSA Chapter 9 requirements regarding discounts for patients at or below 100% FPG, partial discounts for 101-200% FPG, and no discounts above 200% FPG.
compliantItems.evidence: "A nominal flat amount will be charged for patients with at or below 100% of the federal poverty level (FPL)... There will be three discount classes for patients above 100% up to 200% of the FPL. Individuals and families with annual income above two hundred percent (200%) of the FPL are not eligible for sliding fee discount program." AND "Categories/Discount Classes: A = 100% or below FPL; B = >100% -133% FPL; C = >133%-166% FPL; D = >166%-200% FPL; E = >200% or greater of FPL - No Discount- 100% of Fee Schedule/Charge Master as established by CCHC." AND Table: "Nominal/Flat Fee $1.00 $1.25 $1.50 $1.75 $5.00"
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates: (1) a full discount or nominal charge for ≤100% FPG, (2) partial discounts with at least three pay classes for 101-200% FPG, and (3) no discount for >200% FPG. We checked: (1) full discount/nominal charge for ≤100% FPG—SATISFIED: nominal fee of $1.00 for ≤100% FPG is explicitly stated; (2) partial discounts for 101-200% FPG with at least three pay classes—SATISFIED: three discount classes (B, C, D) are shown with explicit income ranges and fees; (3) no discount for >200% FPG—SATISFIED: category E is >200% FPG with no discount and full fee. All items are explicitly documented in the SFDS policy and scale, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element e - Incorporation of Current Federal Poverty Guidelines
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's SFDS(s) has incorporated the most recent FPG.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center's Sliding Fee Discount Schedule (SFDS) incorporates the most recent Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG).
compliantItems.evidence: "The Federal Poverty Levels will be updated annually within a reasonable time of the published annual Federal Poverty Guidelines (FPG)." and "Based on FPG published Jan 13,2018 Will be updated with the 2019 FPG as soon as they are available."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement is that the SFDS must incorporate the most recent Federal Poverty Guidelines. We checked for explicit policy language and documentation of FPG use and update. SATISFIED: The policy states the Federal Poverty Levels are updated annually within a reasonable time of the published FPG, and the sliding fee scale table notes it will be updated with the next available FPG. Both items are directly quoted and clearly satisfy the requirement. Therefore, the application is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Documentation of Key Management Staff Positions
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position (for example, in position descriptions).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center has documented the training and experience qualifications, as well as the duties or functions, for each key management staff position.
compliantItems.evidence: "Job Title: Executive Director, Chuuk Community Health Center... QUALIFICATIONS Minimum of a Bachelor's degree in healthcare or equivalent experience, business or related field of study; Master's degree in a related field is desirable... Minimum of five years of medical/healthcare management experience or equivalent experience sufficient to satisfy the Governing Board that the job can be performed satisfactorily... MAJOR DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Responsible for the overall management of the Public Center, including: Community Relations; Financial Management; Personnel Management; Facilities Management; Planning and Marketing; Operations Management; Support to the Governing Board; Professional Relationships and Networking"; "Job Title: Medical Director, Chuuk Community Health Center... QUALIFICATIONS Licensed to practice medicine in the State of Chuuk, FSM. Minimum of five years of medical/healthcare management experience or equivalent experience sufficient to satisfy the Chuuk Governing Board and Executive Director that the job can be performed satisfactorily... MAJOR DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Responsible for the overall clinical management of the Public Center, including: providing clinical care; administration, including supervision and coordination of all medical activities at all CCHC sites and for all CCHC services..."; "Job Title: Finance Officer, Chuuk Community Health Center... QUALIFICATIONS BA or Associates Degree in accounting or similar field. Able to use calculator and other business equipment. Knowledge of general ledger/computerized accounting systems, federal accounting, fund accounting, and financial management procedures... MAJOR DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES Functions of the position include: assistance with procurement, payroll, billing, collections, reporting, assistance with budget preparation, monitoring and audit and general accounting."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates documentation of training and experience qualifications, as well as duties/functions, for each key management staff position. We checked for explicit position descriptions including qualifications and duties for key management staff. SATISFIED: The application provides detailed job descriptions for the Executive Director, Medical Director, and Finance Officer, each listing required qualifications (education, experience) and major duties/functions. All items are satisfied; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center's Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the health center's governing board and is responsible for overseeing other key management staff in carrying out the day-to-day activities necessary to fulfill the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the Project Director/CEO is directly employed by the health center, reports to the governing board, and oversees key management staff for day-to-day operations within the HRSA-approved scope.
compliantItems.evidence: "The Executive Director reports to the CCHC Governing Board, which has the authority to approve the selection, performance, evaluation, retention, and dismissal of the Executive Director." AND "All staff, including the executive director, are employees of CCHC/CDHS." AND "The CCHC Executive Director oversees a management team consisting of the Physician Site Supervisors of Sapuk, Neou and Nepukos, the Clinical Director, the Finance Officer, and the QA Manager. The Executive Director has full supervisory responsibility for all staff whose FTEs are funded entirely by the CHC."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates that the CEO/Project Director is directly employed by the health center, reports to the governing board, and oversees key management staff in day-to-day operations. We checked: (1) direct employment—SATISFIED: 'All staff, including the executive director, are employees of CCHC/CDHS'; (2) reporting to the board—SATISFIED: 'The Executive Director reports to the CCHC Governing Board, which has the authority to approve the selection, performance, evaluation, retention, and dismissal of the Executive Director'; (3) oversight of management staff—SATISFIED: 'The CCHC Executive Director oversees a management team... has full supervisory responsibility for all staff.' All items are explicitly documented and satisfied. Requirement is compliant.

nonCompliantItems.requirement: If the health center has made a subaward, the health center requested and received prior approval from HRSA as documented by:

nonCompliantItems.requirement: The health center's subaward(s) that supports the HRSA-approved scope of project includes provisions that address the following:

compliantItems.element: Element a - Coordination and Integration of Activities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to collaborate with other providers or programs in the service area, including local hospitals, specialty providers, and social service organizations (including those that serve special populations), to provide access to services not available through the health center in order to support:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of documentation of collaborative efforts with other providers/programs to support reductions in non-urgent ED use, continuity of care, and access to other health/community services.
compliantItems.evidence: "Prior to the establishment of CCHC, all health services were centralized at the hospital in Nepukos. With three new primary care sites equidistantly located throughout the island of Weno, CCHC is having a direct impact on reducing ER visits at the hospital." "Each health center physician currently maintains clinical staff privileges at CSH and follows patients who are admitted to the hospital until discharge. CSH has agreed to take all referrals from CCHC staff. The hospital provides CHCC staff with admission and discharge/followup summaries for all CHCC patients receiving in patient and urgent care." "CDHS operates a variety of public health programs funded through US- and international (WHO) funding sources. CDHS is using the CHC model to decentralize and integrate these programs into the community. Public health programs to be coordinated and/or integrated into CHC service sites include: Maternal and Child Health (MCH)... Family Planning Program... Substance Abuse and Mental Health (SAMHA)... Environmental health... Communicable diseases... Immunization Program... Children with Special Needs... Non-Communicable Disease control..."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit documentation of collaborative efforts with other providers/programs to support (1) reductions in non-urgent ED use, (2) continuity of care, and (3) access to other health/community services. For (1), the application states that the establishment of CCHC primary care sites is directly reducing ER visits. For (2), it details protocols for continuity of care, including staff privileges, referral acceptance, and information sharing between CCHC and the hospital. For (3), it lists coordinated integration with a range of public health and social service programs. All three items are explicitly addressed with direct quotes, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Collaboration with Other Primary Care Providers
compliantItems.requirement: The health center documents its efforts to coordinate and integrate its activities with other federally-funded, as well as State and local, health services delivery projects and programs serving similar patient populations in the service area (at a minimum, this would include establishing and maintaining relationships with other health centers in the service area).
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center documents efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, State, and local health services delivery projects/programs serving similar patient populations in the service area, including relationships with other health centers.
compliantItems.evidence: "The Chuuk Department of Health Services provides the only available health services in Chuuk State. There are no other hospitals, private providers, rural health clinics or FQHCs (besides CCHC) in Chuuk State." and "CDHS operates a variety of public health programs funded through US- and international (WHO) funding sources. CDHS is using the CHC model to decentralize and integrate these programs into the community. Public health programs to be coordinated and/or integrated into CHC service sites include: Maternal and Child Health (MCH)... Family Planning Program... Substance Abuse and Mental Health (SAMHA)... Environmental health... Communicable diseases, including TB & Leprosy and HIV/AIDS... Immunization Program... Children with Special Needs... Non-Communicable Disease control..." and "In preparation for our original NAP, CDHS management, along with the PHS Director and Program Coordinators, met for a planning session focused on 1) CHC opportunities and requirements; 2) examples and models of partnership between CHCs and Public Health Programs in the Pacific; and 3) a CHC/PHS integration plan described in the previous 'Response' section. The plan focuses on: Shared/partnered staffing; Joint training opportunities and transfer of skills; Service integration, especially for case management, referral and on-site PH specialty clinics; Joint community assessment, especially in the first year; Data collection and analysis, including integrating PH registries into CHC case management to identify high risk patient and provide and track in-community service."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates documentation of efforts to coordinate and integrate activities with other federally-funded, State, and local health services delivery projects/programs serving similar populations, including relationships with other health centers. We checked for explicit documentation of such coordination and integration. The application states that CDHS is the only other provider in the service area and details extensive integration and coordination with CDHS public health programs (MCH, Family Planning, SAMHA, etc.), including shared staffing, joint training, service integration, and data sharing. There are no other health centers in the service area, but collaboration with other FSM CHCs is also described. All required items are satisfied with clear, direct evidence.

compliantItems.element: Element h - Policies or Procedures for Waiving or Reducing Fees
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has and utilizes board-approved policies, as well as operating procedures, that include the specific circumstances when the health center will waive or reduce fees or payments required by the center due to any patient's inability to pay.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center has and utilizes board-approved policies and operating procedures specifying the circumstances for waiving or reducing fees due to inability to pay.
compliantItems.evidence: "6. Waiver of fees 6.1 CCHC will ensure that no patient is denied care base on ability to pay and accordingly the waiver of fees will occur on a case by case basis. 6.2 The CEO will be the only one allowed to waive fees based on hardship situation which would cause a barrier to care for a patient. Justification for such waiver will be document and signed off by the CEO and an waiver adjustment code will be set up so that these accounts can be tracked and if necessary used to evaluate the nominal fee amount in the future."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates board-approved policies and procedures that specify when fees may be waived or reduced due to inability to pay. We checked for explicit documentation of (1) board approval, (2) defined circumstances for waiving/reducing fees, and (3) operational procedures for such waivers. All items are SATISFIED: the policy states waivers are allowed on a case-by-case basis for hardship, only the CEO may approve, justification must be documented, and accounts tracked. This is a clear, explicit, board-approved policy and procedure. Requirement is compliant.

nonCompliantItems.element: Element c - Participation in Insurance Programs
nonCompliantItems.requirement: The health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
nonCompliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center participates in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance.
nonCompliantItems.evidence: "Residents of the FSM, including Chuuk State, are not eligible for US federal programs such as Medicaid, Medicare and Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP).
