"We do not receive insurance payments from US Medicare or Medicaid, FSM MiCare, or the Chuuk State Health Plan (as explained in detail above)."
nonCompliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit participation in Medicaid, CHIP, Medicare, and, as appropriate, other public or private assistance programs or health insurance. The application clearly states that residents are not eligible for Medicaid, Medicare, or CHIP, and that the health center does not participate in these programs. While two local insurance plans exist (MiCare and Chuuk State Health Plan), the application also states that the health center does not receive payments from these programs. Therefore, the requirement is NOT satisfied, and the application is NON_COMPLIANT.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Budgeting for Scope of Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center develops and submits to HRSA (for new or continued funding or designation from HRSA) an annual budget, also referred to as a 'total budget,' that reflects projected costs and revenues necessary to support the health center's proposed or HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center develops and submits to HRSA an annual budget reflecting projected costs and revenues necessary to support the HRSA-approved scope of project.
compliantItems.evidence: "A budget, detailed budget justification and all required budget forms have been completed and uploaded as per the guidance." AND "Chuuk Community Health Center Budget Justification April 1, 2024 - March 31, 2025... TOTAL REVENUE 650,000 36,250 686,250... TOTAL DIRECT CHARGES (Sum of TOTAL Expenses) 650,000 36,250 686,250" AND "Annual Budget: Financial planning and budget preparation under the governing board's direction by a committee consisting of representatives of the health center board, executive director of the health center, and financial administrative staff of the health center. Approval of the health center's annual budget."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement is for the health center to develop and submit an annual budget to HRSA that reflects projected costs and revenues for the approved scope of project. We checked for: (1) existence of a completed annual budget, (2) inclusion of projected costs and revenues, and (3) evidence that the budget supports the HRSA-approved scope. All items are satisfied: the application explicitly states the budget and justification were completed and uploaded, provides a detailed annual budget with revenue and expense projections, and describes the board's approval process for the annual budget. Therefore, the requirement is compliant.

nonCompliantItems.requirement: In addition to the Health Center Program award, the health center's annual budget includes all other projected revenue sources that will support the Health Center Program project, specifically:
nonCompliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the annual budget includes all projected revenue sources supporting the Health Center Program project, specifically: (1) fees/premiums/third-party payments, (2) state/local/other federal grants, (3) private support/contributions, (4) any other funding.
nonCompliantItems.evidence: "Fees for Medical Visits 9000 50% 1.25 5,625" and "Fees for Dental Visits 1000 50% 1.25 625" and "LOCAL FUNDS (Chuuk DHS) 30,000" and "TOTAL REVENUE 650,000 36,250 686,250"
nonCompliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit inclusion of all projected revenue sources supporting the Health Center Program project, including fees/premiums/third-party payments, state/local/other federal grants, private support/contributions, and any other funding. We checked: (1) fees/premiums/third-party payments – PARTIALLY SATISFIED: only self-pay nominal fees are listed, no third-party reimbursements or insurance payments are shown; (2) state/local/other federal grants – PARTIALLY SATISFIED: local funds from Chuuk DHS are listed, but no other federal grants (e.g., Ryan White, Healthy Start) are identified; (3) private support/contributions – NOT SATISFIED: there is no evidence of private support or contributions; (4) any other funding – PARTIALLY SATISFIED: only program income and local funds are listed, no other sources. Because at least one required item (private support/contributions) is not addressed and third-party payments are not included, the application is NON_COMPLIANT.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Maintenance of Board Authority Over Health Center Project
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's organizational structure, articles of incorporation, bylaws, and other relevant documents ensure the health center governing board maintains the authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, specifically:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center governing board maintains authority for oversight of the Health Center Program project, with no other entity reserving approval/veto power, collaborations do not infringe on board authority, and a co-applicant agreement delegates required authorities.
compliantItems.evidence: "The Governing Board shall have and is vested with the full power and authority of CCHC except as bay be expressly limited by the laws of Chuuk State or these Bylaws." "no other entity or entities may select a majority of Chuuk Community Health Center governing board members as well as the majority of the non-user members." "the Chuuk Community Health Center governing board will have authority to establish policies for delivery services of the Community Health Center, which shall include but not limited to: a) Scope and availability of services... g) Budgeting as are consistent with the FQHC Application..." "The co-applicant agreement, reviewed by the Board and CDHS and signed by the CDHS Director of Health Services and CCHC Board Chair, identifies the respective domains of Board, CDHS and joint responsibility for governance, in full compliance with HRSA PIN 2014-01 Health Center Program Governance, as it applies to public centers."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates that the board retains full authority over the health center project, with no other entity reserving approval/veto power, collaborations do not infringe on board authority, and a co-applicant agreement delegates required authorities. We checked: (1) Board authority is not subject to veto/approval by others—SATISFIED: bylaws and co-applicant agreement state board has full authority and no other entity can select or remove board members; (2) Collaborations do not infringe on board authority—SATISFIED: no contracts/subawards for programmatic work, and agreements specify board retains authority; (3) Co-applicant agreement delegates required authorities—SATISFIED: agreement explicitly delegates authorities and delineates roles. All items are satisfied with explicit evidence.

compliantItems.element: Element b - Required Authorities and Responsibilities
compliantItems.requirement: The health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents outline the following required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation that the health center's articles of incorporation, bylaws, or other relevant documents explicitly outline the seven required authorities and responsibilities of the governing board.
compliantItems.evidence: "Section 2.2. Responsibility - The Governing Board has ultimate responsibility for the operations of CCHC. Governing Board Responsibilities are divided into the following functional areas: ... Selecting, dismissing and evaluating the executive director ... Monitoring and evaluating the performance of services ... Approve the health center's grant application and annual budget ... Establishing and monitoring all other policies necessary for the effective administration of services provided by CCHC ... In performing these duties, the Governing Board shall monitor compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates that the governing board's authorities and responsibilities are explicitly outlined in foundational documents. We checked all seven required items: (1) monthly meetings, (2) CEO selection/termination, (3) annual budget/applications, (4) services/location/hours, (5) performance evaluation, (6) policy establishment, (7) legal compliance. Each item is directly addressed in the bylaws and/or co-applicant agreement with clear, explicit language. All items are satisfied with direct quotes, so the requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.element: Element a - Board Member Selection and Removal Process
compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members. This board member selection and removal process does not permit any other entity, committee or individual (other than the board) to select either the board chair or the majority of health center board members, including a majority of the non-patient board members.
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center has bylaws or other documents specifying the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members, and that no other entity, committee, or individual (other than the board) may select the board chair or majority of board members.
compliantItems.evidence: "Section 3.4. Election to Governing Board Membership - The Governing Board shall be a self-perpetuating Governing board. Governing Board members shall elect their peers and or others to Governing Board positions as needed at the monthly meetings. The Membership Committee shall present to the Annual Meeting a list of eligible and consenting proposed persons to replace members of the Governing Board." AND "Section 3.6. Vacancies - Any vacancy arising between annual meetings may be filled by the majority vote of the Governing Board, selecting an eligible, consenting person." AND from the co-applicant agreement: "h) Shall have the full authority to nominate and select all members of its governing board as prescribed in the Chuuk Community Health Center board by-laws; no other entity or entities may select a majority of Chuuk Community Health Center governing board members as well as the majority of the non-user members. i) Shall elect the Board President as well as majority of members of the Executive Committee; neither the Chuuk DHS, nor any other entity may select the board president and majority of members of the Executive Committee. j) Shall have the authority to remove member(s) from the board; neither the Chuuk DHS, nor any other entity may dismiss member(s) of Chuuk Community Health Center governing board."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates that the health center's bylaws or other documents specify the process for ongoing selection and removal of board members, and that no other entity, committee, or individual (other than the board) may select the board chair or majority of board members. We checked: (1) existence of a documented process for selection/removal—SATISFIED: bylaws state the board is self-perpetuating and fills vacancies by majority vote; (2) restriction on outside entities selecting board chair or majority—SATISFIED: co-applicant agreement and bylaws explicitly state only the board has this authority, and no other entity may select or remove board members or the chair. All items are satisfied with clear, direct evidence; requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has bylaws or other relevant documents that require the board to be composed as follows:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of HRSA Chapter 20: Board Composition, Element b - Required Board Composition, including all 7 specific board composition requirements.
compliantItems.evidence: "Section 3.1. Size of Governing Board - The Governing Board will consist of no less than 9 and no more than 25 members"; "At least fifty -one (51) percent of Governing Board members shall be users of CCHC"; "The Governing Board shall represent the community in which the service area is located and the individuals being served by CCHC in terms of demographic factors such as race, ethnicity and sex"; "No member of the Governing Board shall be an employee of CCHC (which includes the Chuuk Department of Health Services CDHS as the co-applicant) - or a spouse, child, parent, brother or sister by blood or marriage of such an employee."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit board composition policies covering size, patient majority, demographic/community representation, expertise, health industry income limits, and conflict of interest. We checked all 7 items. Each is directly addressed in the bylaws and/or co-applicant agreement: (1) board size range, (2) 51%+ users, (3) demographic representation, (4) non-patient community representation, (5) expertise, (6) health industry income limit, (7) employee/family exclusion. All items are satisfied with clear, direct evidence. Requirement is compliant.

compliantItems.requirement: The health center has documentation that the board is composed of:
compliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validated that the health center board composition meets all HRSA requirements for size, patient majority, demographic representation, special populations, and non-patient member criteria.
compliantItems.evidence: "Board composition and bylaws comply fully with HRSA governance requirements for composition (9 to 25 board members; user majority; representation from the communities served; an array of relevant expertise; restrictions on health industry remuneration among members; and restrictions on nepotism). The Board currently has nine members. One hundred percent of the board are users of the health centers. The board has representation from each service site, as per below. The board includes the following expertise: ..."
compliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit documentation that the board has 9-25 members, a patient majority, demographic representation, special population representation (if applicable), and that non-patient members meet HRSA criteria. We checked: (1) board size - SATISFIED: bylaws and narrative state 9-25 members and current board is 9; (2) patient majority - SATISFIED: bylaws require 51% users and narrative states 100% are users; (3) demographic representation - SATISFIED: bylaws and narrative require and describe representation by race, ethnicity, and sex; (4) special populations - SATISFIED: Form 1A and narrative show no 330(g), (h), or (i) funding, so not applicable; (5) non-patient member criteria - SATISFIED: bylaws and Form 6A show no more than 50% earn >10% from health care, and all live/work in the community. All items are explicitly addressed with direct evidence, so the requirement is compliant.

nonCompliantItems.requirement: In cases where a health center receives an award/designation under section 330(g), 330(h) and/or 330(i), does not receive an award/designation under section 330(e), and requests a waiver of the patient majority board composition requirements, the health center presents to HRSA for review and approval:
nonCompliantItems.whatWasChecked: Validation of HRSA Board Composition waiver requirements for special population health centers, specifically documentation of 'good cause' for waiver and strategies for patient input.
nonCompliantItems.reasoning: The requirement mandates explicit documentation of (1) 'good cause' for a waiver of patient majority board composition, including unique population characteristics and recruitment attempts, and (2) strategies for ensuring patient participation in governance. After a thorough review of the entire application, there is no direct evidence of a waiver request, justification of 'good cause,' documentation of recruitment attempts, or a description of alternative patient input strategies as required for a board composition waiver. Form 6B states the waiver is 'not applicable,' and no narrative or attachments elsewhere address these items. Therefore, the application is NON_COMPLIANT.
